rows.text_1_facilitator:
Today we are learning to talk about feelings with our children. 

Noticing emotions, both our own and our children's, helps us care for ourselves. 

Noticing and talking about feelings with our children helps them learn to express and manage their emotions ‚Äì even the difficult ones.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
Today we are learning to talk about feelings with our children. 

Noticing emotions, both our own and our children's, helps us care for ourselves. 

Noticing and talking about feelings with our children helps them learn to express and manage their emotions ‚Äì even the difficult ones.

media_title.eng: How will it help you and your family?

media_transcript.eng:
Greetings, everyone.

Does your child ever get so upset that you don‚Äôt know what to do? 

You can help your child to manage their emotions better by showing them how to talk about their feelings. In order to talk about feelings you need to first notice and then accept all the emotions we have.

rows.media_title: How will it help you and your family?
rows.media_transcript:
Greetings, everyone.

Does your child ever get so upset that you don‚Äôt know what to do? 

You can help your child to manage their emotions better by showing them how to talk about their feelings. In order to talk about feelings you need to first notice and then accept all the emotions we have.

rows.text_1_facilitator: Let‚Äôs look at another family to see how talking about feelings helps them in a practical way:

text_1_facilitator.eng: Let‚Äôs look at another family to see how talking about feelings helps them in a practical way:

character_1_text.eng: @data.characters.f3_son_4.name, I have 5 minutes to spend one-on-one time with you. What would you like to do?

character_2_text.eng: Let‚Äôs play with the ball outside!

rows.character_1_text: @data.characters.f3_son_4.name, I have 5 minutes to spend one-on-one time with you. What would you like to do?
rows.character_2_text: Let‚Äôs play with the ball outside!

character_2_text.eng: I see that your hands are tight and you are speaking loudly. It looks like you are upset, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name. It‚Äôs not easy, let‚Äôs practise a little bit more. I know you can do it.

rows.character_2_text: I see that your hands are tight and you are speaking loudly. It looks like you are upset, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name. It‚Äôs not easy, let‚Äôs practise a little bit more. I know you can do it.

rows.character_1_text: Five kicks in a row! You seem really proud to have made it to five, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name!

character_1_text.eng: Five kicks in a row! You seem really proud to have made it to five, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name!

rows.character_1_text: Well done! I am very happy to be able to spend this time with you, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name

character_1_text.eng: Well done! I am very happy to be able to spend this time with you, @data.characters.f3_son_4.name

rows.text_1_facilitator: Let‚Äôs talk this through together. What happened when @data.characters.f3_uncle.name and @data.characters.f3_son_4.name decided to play soccer?

text_1_facilitator.eng: Let‚Äôs talk this through together. What happened when @data.characters.f3_uncle.name and @data.characters.f3_son_4.name decided to play soccer?

quiz_1_question.eng: Why does @data.characters.f3_uncle.name name @data.characters.f3_son_4.name‚Äôs feelings when he‚Äôs feeling angry?

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: Not quite. Naming emotions might not make someone feel better right away. The goal is to help him recognize his feelings so he can handle them better next time.

quiz_1_option_2_text.eng: To help @data.characters.f3_son_4.name learn to recognise his own emotions

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: That‚Äôs right. By naming @data.characters.f3_son_4.name‚Äôs emotions, @data.characters.f3_uncle.name models an important skill.

quiz_1_option_3_text.eng: To teach @data.characters.f3_son_4.name how to solve problems on his own.

quiz_1_feedback_3.eng: Not really. While solving problems is important, the main goal here is to help @data.characters.f3_son_4.name recognize his emotions. Once he knows what he‚Äôs feeling, he‚Äôll be better at solving problems next time.

quiz_1_option_4_text.eng: To distract @data.characters.f3_son_4.name from what‚Äôs bothering him.

quiz_1_feedback_4.eng: Not quite. The goal isn‚Äôt to take his mind off his feelings. By naming his emotions, @data.characters.f3_uncle.name is helping @data.characters.f3_son_4.name understand what he‚Äôs feeling, so he can deal with it better next time.

quiz_2_question.eng: What can we learn from how @data.characters.f3_uncle.name talks about @data.characters.f3_son_4.name‚Äôs emotions?

quiz_2_feedback_1.eng: Yes, he does! But he also names @data.characters.f3_son_4.name‚Äôs difficult emotions. @data.characters.f3_uncle.name shows us that it is important to identify both positive *and* difficult emotions for our children.

quiz_2_option_2_text.eng: He doesn‚Äôt want him to feel frustrated so he ignores it.

quiz_2_feedback_2.eng: Not quite. @data.characters.f3_uncle.name accepts whatever emotions @data.characters.f3_son_4.name is feeling. @data.characters.f3_uncle.name shows us how we can talk about positive *and* difficult emotions with our children in a helpful way.

quiz_2_option_3_text.eng: He uses words to describe @data.characters.f3_son_4.name‚Äôs emotions

quiz_2_feedback_3.eng: Yes, @data.characters.f3_uncle.name shows us how we can talk about positive *and* difficult emotions with our children in a helpful way.

quiz_2_option_4_text.eng: He hides his own feelings with @data.characters.f3_son_4.name

quiz_2_feedback_4.eng: He doesn‚Äôt hide his own emotions, he names them. By talking about his own feeling of happiness, @data.characters.f3_uncle.name models how his nephew can do the same.

quiz_2_feedback_5.eng: Yes, @data.characters.f3_uncle.name shows us that his nephew‚Äôs difficult emotions are not something he needs to ignore or be scared of.

quiz_3_question.eng: What would have happened if @data.characters.f3_uncle.name had criticised or ignored @data.characters.f3_son_4.name‚Äôs frustration?

quiz_3_feedback_1.eng: Incorrect. Without the ability to deal with his feelings, the frustration @data.characters.f3_son_4.name was feeling would have increased.

quiz_3_option_2_text.eng: The same problem would happen again next time

quiz_3_feedback_2.eng: Correct. Noticing and naming emotions is very important to support our children and help them learn how to deal with their emotions.

quiz_3_option_3_text.eng: @data.characters.f3_son_4.name would have learned how to catch a ball anyway.

quiz_3_feedback_3.eng: Incorrect. Noticing and naming emotions is very important to support our children and help them learn new skills.

rows.text_1_facilitator:
**Notice Feelings** 
- Feelings are connected to thoughts and physical sensations.
- Notice when your child is feeling good and when they are feeling bad.
- Recognise both positive and difficult emotions.
- To recognise, pay attention to your thoughts and to your and your child‚Äôs words and actions.

**Accept Feelings** 
- Be open to how you and your child feel. Accept both negative and positive emotions. All feelings are okay.
- Acknowledge your child‚Äôs feelings ‚Äì even the difficult ones.
- It is okay for you to also feel difficult emotions about the same issues.
- The six basic emotions each have a message:
üòä Happy ‚Üí Keep doing what makes you feel good.
‚òπÔ∏è Sad ‚Üí Something important needs attention.
üò† Angry ‚Üí Stand up for yourself and set limits.
ü§¢ Disgusted ‚Üí Move away from something you don‚Äôt like.
üòØ Surprised ‚Üí Stop and pay attention.
üò® Afraid ‚Üí Run away from danger.
- As children get older, they also learn about other emotions such as excitement, frustration, pride, loneliness, peace, guilt, or confusion.

**Talk about your feelings** 
- Get down to your child‚Äôs level when talking about feelings.
- Use physical and verbal support to make your child feel accepted and loved.
- Commenting on your child‚Äôs feelings can help him/her learn self-discipline and emotional awareness
- Use words to describe your child‚Äôs emotions so they can learn to do the same. This may be hard at first, but it is an important step to help manage emotions! 
- Describe what you notice in a calm way: ‚ÄúI notice you‚Äôre stomping your feet, talking loudly, and your face looks upset. What are you feeling?‚Äù
- Share your own feelings with your child. For example, ‚ÄúI know I feel the same way when I can‚Äôt go out when I want to.‚Äù
- When you share your own feelings with your child, you help your child recognise his/her own emotions. 
- By sharing your own feelings, you also show your child that it's okay to share their feelings. They will learn to recognise emotions in themselves and others too. 
- Model the behaviour you want to see in your child.

text_1_facilitator.eng:
**Notice Feelings** 
- Feelings are connected to thoughts and physical sensations.
- Notice when your child is feeling good and when they are feeling bad.
- Recognise both positive and difficult emotions.
- To recognise, pay attention to your thoughts and to your and your child‚Äôs words and actions.

**Accept Feelings** 
- Be open to how you and your child feel. Accept both negative and positive emotions. All feelings are okay.
- Acknowledge your child‚Äôs feelings ‚Äì even the difficult ones.
- It is okay for you to also feel difficult emotions about the same issues.
- The six basic emotions each have a message:
üòä Happy ‚Üí Keep doing what makes you feel good.
‚òπÔ∏è Sad ‚Üí Something important needs attention.
üò† Angry ‚Üí Stand up for yourself and set limits.
ü§¢ Disgusted ‚Üí Move away from something you don‚Äôt like.
üòØ Surprised ‚Üí Stop and pay attention.
üò® Afraid ‚Üí Run away from danger.
- As children get older, they also learn about other emotions such as excitement, frustration, pride, loneliness, peace, guilt, or confusion.

**Talk about your feelings** 
- Get down to your child‚Äôs level when talking about feelings.
- Use physical and verbal support to make your child feel accepted and loved.
- Commenting on your child‚Äôs feelings can help him/her learn self-discipline and emotional awareness
- Use words to describe your child‚Äôs emotions so they can learn to do the same. This may be hard at first, but it is an important step to help manage emotions! 
- Describe what you notice in a calm way: ‚ÄúI notice you‚Äôre stomping your feet, talking loudly, and your face looks upset. What are you feeling?‚Äù
- Share your own feelings with your child. For example, ‚ÄúI know I feel the same way when I can‚Äôt go out when I want to.‚Äù
- When you share your own feelings with your child, you help your child recognise his/her own emotions. 
- By sharing your own feelings, you also show your child that it's okay to share their feelings. They will learn to recognise emotions in themselves and others too. 
- Model the behaviour you want to see in your child.

section_1_text.eng: Recognise the *positive* and *difficult* emotions that you and your child feel.

section_1_extra_text.eng: To recognise feelings, pay attention to your thoughts and to your and your child‚Äôs words and actions.

section_2_text.eng: Be open to how you and your child feel. All feelings are okay.

section_2_extra_text.eng:
There are six basic emotions. Each send us an important message:

üòä Happy: Keep doing things that make you feel good. 

‚òπÔ∏è Sad: Something important in your life needs attention.

üò† Angry: Stand up for yourself and set limits.

ü§¢ Disgusted: Move away from something you don't like.

üòØ Surprised: Stop and pay attention for a moment.

üò® Afraid: Run away from danger.
 
As children get older, they learn to identify lots of other emotions, like feeling excited, frustrated, proud, lonely, peaceful, guilty, or confused.

section_3_text.eng:
Use words to describe your and your child‚Äôs emotions, so they can learn to do the same. 
 
This may be hard at first, but it is an important step to help manage emotions!

section_3_extra_text.eng:
Describe how you see your child‚Äôs emotion in a calm way. For example:
 
*‚ÄúI notice you‚Äôre stomping your feet, talking loudly, and your face looks a bit upset. What are you feeling?‚Äù*
 
Share your own feelings with your child. For example: 
 
*‚ÄúI know I feel the same way when I can‚Äôt go out when I want to.‚Äù*
 
This shows your child that it's okay to share their feelings. They will learn to recognise emotions in themselves and others too.

üò® Afraid: Run away from danger.
 
As children get older, they learn to identify lots of other emotions, like feeling excited, frustrated, proud, lonely, peaceful, guilty, or confused.

This shows your child that it's okay to share their feelings. They will learn to recognise emotions in themselves and others too.

rows.text_1_facilitator: Let‚Äôs put the tips you have learnt in action:

text_1_facilitator.eng: Let‚Äôs put the tips you have learnt in action:

quiz_1_question.eng: @data.characters.f1_mother.name's son is throwing a tantrum at the front door. It's time to put on his shoes and the family is running late. Tying his shoes is a challenge and he wants to do it himself. How can @data.characters.f1_mother.name respond?

quiz_1_option_1_text.eng: Tie his shoes for him and get out the door. We are late!

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: It is never fun to run late, but @data.characters.f1_mother.name will miss the opportunity to help her son learn to deal with his frustration if she doesn't help him first recognise what he‚Äôs feeling.

quiz_1_option_2_text.eng: Understand that her son is feeling frustrated. Sit down and help him name his feelings.

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: That's a great idea. She can also commit to practising shoe tying with him later, when he's more calm and praise him for naming his feelings and for the good effort during their practise session!

rows.quiz_1_question: @data.characters.f1_mother.name's son is throwing a tantrum at the front door. It's time to put on his shoes and the family is running late. Tying his shoes is a challenge and he wants to do it himself. How can @data.characters.f1_mother.name respond?
rows.quiz_1_option_1_text: Tie his shoes for him and get out the door. We are late!
rows.quiz_1_feedback_1: It is never fun to run late, but @data.characters.f1_mother.name will miss the opportunity to help her son learn to deal with his frustration if she doesn't help him first recognise what he‚Äôs feeling.
rows.quiz_1_option_2_text: Understand that her son is feeling frustrated. Sit down and help him name his feelings.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_2: That's a great idea. She can also commit to practising shoe tying with him later, when he's more calm and praise him for naming his feelings and for the good effort during their practise session!

rows.text_1_facilitator: Your home activity is to talk with your child about their feelings during one-on-one time today. It can be something simple, like noticing that they find joy when they play!

text_1_facilitator.eng: Your home activity is to talk with your child about their feelings during one-on-one time today. It can be something simple, like noticing that they find joy when they play!

quiz_1_question.eng: Are you up for trying? Can you help your child notice their feelings during one-on-one time today?

quiz_1_feedback_1.eng: That's great! It might be awkward to talk about feelings at first, but it will get better for everyone with practice.

quiz_1_feedback_2.eng: That's okay. Learning to share emotions with our children can be challenging. Take a minute after one-on-one time today to think through the emotions you saw your child display. You might also want to think about the things that you felt!

rows.quiz_1_question: Are you up for trying? Can you help your child notice their feelings during one-on-one time today?
rows.quiz_1_feedback_1: That's great! It might be awkward to talk about feelings at first, but it will get better for everyone with practice.
rows.quiz_1_feedback_2: That's okay. Learning to share emotions with our children can be challenging. Take a minute after one-on-one time today to think through the emotions you saw your child display. You might also want to think about the things that you felt!
